tossups.question: Description acceptable. Pasi Sahlberg described how these metrics, as assessed by PISA, stayed steady in Finland despite no longer being used to assess outcomes. Joe Louis Clark enforced draconian disciplinary measures to improve these metrics, as described in Jonathan Kozol’s The Shame of the Nation. The steady decline in these metrics over a twenty-year period was a key concern outlined in the report A Nation At Risk. According to Diane Ravitch, because these metrics are (*) normed on a bell curve, the use of these metrics to ensure “accountability” actually enforces the achievement gap. The No Child Left Behind Act made the funding of public schools dependent on their students’ values for these metrics. For 10 points, what metrics are used to determine if students meet Common Core standards?
tossups.answer: standardized test scores [accept standardized testing performance or equivalents; prompt on tests; prompt on academic or educational performance or achievement by asking, “What metric is used to gauge academic performance?”]
tossups.answer_formatted: standardized test scores [accept standardized testing performance or equivalents; prompt on tests; prompt on academic or educational performance or achievement by asking, “What metric is used to gauge academic performance?]
promptable: achievement by asking, “What metric is used to gauge academic performance?

tossups.question: Pocklington’s integral equation is used to model these devices by the method of moments. Rayleigh and Rician distributions model how complex environments attenuate signals detected by these devices. In order to reduce their VSWR to below 1.5, VNAs are used to impedance match these terminal devices. An increasing time delay is introduced to a series of these devices to control the direction of their output in a phased array. The characteristic (*) far-field pattern of these devices has a dumbbell-shaped main lobe and several sidelobes. These components are the detectors in RFID devices. The directivity of these devices is proportional to their length and is low for half-wave dipole designs. Feeding the output of an LC circuit to one of these devices makes it a transmitter. For 10 points, name these devices that receive radio waves.
tossups.answer: antennas [or antennae; prompt on transmitters or receivers]

tossups.question: This man said, “I have not yet made my peace with him,” when asked why he refused to execute his ex-wife’s second husband, Gaius Asinius Gallus. This ruler ordered the execution of the slave Clemens, who had impersonated a former rival of this ruler. It’s not Nero, but this ruler likely appointed Gnaeus Piso as Governor of Syria to curb the ambitions of his nephew. This man was forced to divorce his wife, (*) Vispania, in order to marry a woman who would later be exiled to Pandateria. Three years after the death of his son Drusus, this emperor retired to Capri and allowed the praetorian prefect Sejanus to take power. Jesus preached during the reign of this third husband of Julia the Elder. For 10 points, name this second emperor of Rome, who succeeded Augustus.
tossups.answer: Tiberius [or Tiberius Caesar Augustus or Tiberius Claudius Nero]

tossups.question: Note to moderator: please read the answerline carefully. In a play titled for this literary action, the character who performs this action becomes a factory worker after living through the hypercapitalism of the 1930s; that play is by Elfriede Jelinek. A speech titled for this action discusses the importance of fighting for economic rights in China and was given at a Beijing women’s college; that Lu Xun speech asks “What Happens After [this action]?” A woman explains that she is doing this action after saying she has never had a (*) serious conversation in an eight-year marriage with a man who calls her “my little squirrel.” In a play’s final line, a man asks, “The most wonderful thing of all—?” before he is cut off by the sound of a slamming door, which signifies this action. For 10 points, name this action taken by Nora Helmer at the end of A Doll’s House by Henrik Ibsen.
tossups.answer: Nora leaving her husband [or leaving Torvald Helmer, or leaving her family, or ending her marriage, or equivalents; accept “What Happens After Nora Walks Out?” or “What Happens After Nora Leaves Home?;” prompt on slamming the door or equivalents by asking, “What does that signify?;” prompt on partial answer]
tossups.answer_formatted: Nora leaving her husband [or leaving Torvald Helmer, or leaving her family, or ending her marriage, or equivalents; accept What Happens After Nora Walks Out? or What Happens After Nora Leaves Home?; ” prompt on slamming the door or equivalents by asking, “What does that signify?; ” prompt on partial answer]
acceptable: What Happens After Nora Walks Out?
What Happens After Nora Leaves Home?

tossups.question: Friedrich Chrysander compiled the first full edition of one composer’s pieces for this instrument with Johannes Brahms. An optional violin accompanies this instrument in a set of pieces “in concert” that follows a solo volume featuring the rondeau “Les sauvages,” later used in its composer’s racist Les Indes galantes (“layz AND gah-LAHNT”). Eight short, unmeasured works comprise a text on this instrument by a composer nicknamed “Le Grand.” That court composer included The (*) Mysterious Barricades in the sixth of his 27 “orders” of pieces for this instrument. Jean-Philippe Rameau gave this instrument an obbligato melody instead of chords above basso continuo in book three of his Piéces de clavecin (“p’YES duh clahv-SAN”). For 10 points, François Couperin wrote a treatise on the art of playing what predecessor of the piano, whose strings are plucked?
tossups.answer: harpsichord [accept clavecin until read]

tossups.question: The Twenty Statements Test is used to measure impressions of this concept. A 1991 article by Kitayama and Markus introduces the notion of interdependent and independent construals of this concept, which are illustrated by examples of Asian and Western cultures. Charles Cooley's model of this concept analogizes it to a looking glass because it is defined by outside perception. This is the first of two concepts in a trait that represents the belief people have in their (*) ability to complete a task, according to Albert Bandura. The “dramaturgical approach” was introduced in an Erving Goffman book about the “presentation” of this concept in everyday life. The highest stage of Maslow's hierarchy of needs is the “actualization” of this concept. For 10 points, name this concept for which narcissists have high esteem.
tossups.answer: the self [accept self-construal or self-concept; prompt on identity by asking “What is the related term?;” do not accept or prompt on “self-efficacy”]
tossups.answer_formatted: the self [accept self-construal or self-concept; prompt on identity by asking “What is the related term?; ” do not accept or prompt on “self-efficacy”]

tossups.question: This novel’s protagonist refuses to attend her sister’s wedding, saying that weddings are “lamentable spectacles.” A widow in black with a velvet prayer book follows two lovers on the beach in this novel. A “mother-woman” can’t understand when the protagonist of this novel says that she’d give her life for her children, but not herself. At a dinner party for her twenty-ninth birthday, this novel’s protagonist forcibly covers Victor’s mouth as he (*) sings “Si tu savais” (“sah-VAY”). This novel’s protagonist sells her sketches to move into the pigeon-house, mirroring a caged parrot who shouts, “Allez-vous!” at the beginning of this novel. Dr. Mandelet suspects the protagonist of this novel is having an affair with Robert LeBrun. For 10 points, Edna Pontellier drowns herself in the Gulf of Mexico in what novel by Kate Chopin?
tossups.answer: The Awakening

tossups.question: In the opening of a ballet from this country, a group of dancers in earthen colors at various heights lower their heads as they extend their arms to the sides. A dancer carrying an umbrella crosses ribbons of blue silk in that ballet from this country. A choreographer from this country blended ballet with polyrhythmic dances observed in her anthropological studies. A dance technique from this country is based on (*) “contraction and release.” A rocking chair features in Isamu Noguchi’s minimalist set for a ballet from this country. “Blood memories” of a choreographer from this country inspired his Revelations. The hymn “Simple Gifts” accompanies another ballet from this country. For 10 points, name this country home to Alvin Ailey, Katherine Dunham, and Martha Graham, the choreographer of Appalachian Spring.
tossups.answer: United States of America [or USA or America] (The third clue refers to Katherine Dunham.)
tossups.metadata: The third clue refers to Katherine Dunham.

tossups.question: The M2 isoform of an enzyme that yields this compound promotes tumor angiogenesis when circulated in blood. After G6PDH deficiency, deficiency of this molecule’s namesake kinase is the most common cause of enzyme-deficient hemolytic anemia. In the E1 unit of one enzyme complex, this compound binds to a carb·an·ionic TPP adduct, after which its decarboxylated form is transferred onto the lipo·lysyl arm of the E2 unit. In another enzyme, a (*) biotin “swinging arm” carboxylates this compound’s enolate form. Transferring electrons from NADH to this compound forms lactate. Dephosphorylating PEP yields this compound, whose namesake dehydrogenase oxidizes it to acetyl-CoA for use in the Krebs cycle. For 10 points, glucose is converted into what 3-carbon end product of glycolysis?
tossups.answer: pyruvate [accept pyruvic acid; accept pyruvate kinase; accept pyruvate dehydrogenase; accept pyruvate carboxylase]
tossups.answer_formatted: pyruvate [accept pyruvic acid; accept pyruvate kinase; accept pyruvate dehydrogenase; accept pyruvate carboxylase]

tossups.question: During a battle in this war, an officer claimed that, upon glimpsing the opposing commander, he threw his binoculars and screamed insults at him. One commander in this war sidelined, then brought back his Signal Corps when he realized that no one else could interpret “wig-wag” signals. Catesby ap Roger Jones commanded a ship during this war whose construction was supervised by Stephen (*) Mallory. After one of his ships hit a mine during this war, a commander gambled on maneuvering his entire fleet through the same minefield, apocryphally giving the order “Damn the torpedoes.” The Cumberland and Minnesota were destroyed by an opposing ironclad during this war. For 10 points, name this war in which the Monitor and Virginia fought the Battle of Hampton Roads.
tossups.answer: American Civil War

tossups.question: It’s not French, but a poem in this language describes “phantasmal fireflies in nuptial shadows” and is grouped into three “Nocturnes.” An essay in this language contrasts beauty and utilitarianism by analogizing them to Ariel and Caliban. The title character is told, “You are cultured, you are clever, you oppose Tolstoy,” in a poem in this language that appears in the collection Songs of Life and Hope. A (*) Parnassian-inspired poetry collection in this language includes a “lyrical year.” The narrator notes that the addressee “lacks one thing: God!” at the end of a poem in this language addressed to Theodore Roosevelt. An offshoot of modernism formed after the publication of a collection in this language whose title translates to “Blue….” For 10 points, name this language used by Rubén Darío and other modernismo authors.
tossups.answer: Spanish [or español; accept Castilian or castellano] (The first sentence refers to Nocturno by José Asunción Silva, and the second sentence refers to “Ariel” by José Enrique Rodó.)
tossups.metadata: The first sentence refers to Nocturno by José Asunción Silva, and the second sentence refers to “Ariel” by José Enrique Rodó.

tossups.question: In a now-retracted study, Benny Peiser calculated instances of this position in peer-reviewed publications, refuting the lack of instances posited in a non-Derek Bok article titled “Beyond the Ivory Tower.” The “Tobacco Strategy” influenced Fred Seitz’s and Fred Singer’s legitimation of this position following the collapse of the Soviet Union according to a 2010 book by Naomi Oreskes and Eric M. Conway. The most recent examples of the title Merchants of (*) Doubt lend credence to this position, whose adherents disparage Michael Mann’s “hockey stick” graph that visualizes human impact during the Anthropocene. Oklahoma Senator Jim Inhofe championed this position by bringing a snowball to the Capitol. For 10 points, give this position that rejects a scientific consensus about human impact on rising global temperatures.
tossups.answer: climate change denial [accept climate skepticism]

tossups.question: Seifert manifolds are fiber bundles whose fibers are this set. A topological space is simply connected if every map from this set to the space is contractible to a point. In algebraic topology, this is the simplest set whose fundamental group is the integers and whose universal covering is the reals. This set is isomorphic to the quotient group R/Z and SO(2), the group of 2D rotation matrices. All connected and closed 1D-manifolds are homeomorphic to this set. The (*) torus is often defined as the Cartesian product of this set with itself. Roots of unity are visualized as being equally spaced apart on this set, which is isomorphic to the complex numbers with magnitude one. This set, which is parametrized as (cosine t, sine t), is the boundary of the unit disk. For 10 points, give this shape represented in the plane as x 2 + y 2 = 1.
tossups.answer: unit circle [accept S 1 or the 1-sphere; accept the circle group; accept U(1)]
tossups.answer_formatted: unit circle [accept S 1 or the 1-sphere; accept the circle group; accept U(1)]

tossups.question: ANSWER: unit circle [accept S 1 or the 1-sphere; accept the circle group; accept U(1)] <VD, Other Science: Math and Computer Science> 14. In a Southeast Asian motif, one of these animals named Mucalinda shelters the meditating Buddha from rain. A Tirthankara who instituted the “fourfold restraint,” Parshvanatha, is often depicted with a canopy of these animals over his head. A weapon belonging to Ravana’s son, Indrajit, incapacitated enemies with these animals. In the Bhagavad Gita, Krishna asserts that “of [these beings], I am Ananta.” A netherworld of jeweled palaces called Patala is home to these children of (*) Kadru. Krishna subdues one of these animals by dancing on its heads, while another one of them floats on the cosmic ocean supporting Vishnu. Kaliya and Shesha are examples of these animals, and a race of half-human, half-these animals are the enemies of Garuda. For 10 points, the nagas take the form of what animals?
tossups.answer: snakes [or serpents; or any of nagas, naginis, or nagis, until “nagas” read]
tossups.answer_formatted: snakes [or serpents; or any of nagas, naginis, or nagis, until “nagas” read]

tossups.question: Opponents to reform efforts during this dynasty were convicted in the Crow Terrace Poetry Trial. During this dynasty, the Sū brothers formed the Sìchuān Faction to oppose bureaucratic reforms that built upon the Qìnglì Reforms of Fàn Zhòngyān and Ōuyáng Xiū (“OH-yahng tsee-O”). A boost in agricultural production was the goal of “green shoots loans” instituted during this dynasty. Households were organized into groups of tens and hundreds for local defense purposes in the (*) bǎojiǎ system developed during this dynasty. That system was part of the New Policies promoted by Wáng Ānshí. By capturing Kāifēng, the Jurchens ended this dynasty’s “Northern” period in 1127. For 10 points, name this Chinese dynasty conquered by the Mongols, who established the subsequent Yuán dynasty.
tossups.answer: Sòng dynasty [or Sòng cháo; accept Northern Sòng dynasty or Southern Sòng dynasty]
tossups.answer_formatted: Sòng dynasty [or Sòng cháo; accept Northern Sòng dynasty or Southern Sòng dynasty]

tossups.question: Mary Shepherd argues, contrary to this book, that inherent qualities of objects give rise to their “power,” or “productive principle.” A critique in this book has posed the most decisive attack on metaphysics as a science, according to the preface of Kant’s Prolegomena. This book puts forth resemblance, contiguity, and causation as the three principles of association, and argues that our idea of causation arises from our observation of (*) “constant conjunction” between events. This book introduces the “copy principle” to explain how simple ideas arise from impressions. This book argues that our evidence for the laws of nature will always outweigh evidence for single supernatural events in its tenth chapter, “Of Miracles.” For 10 points, name this work of epistemology by David Hume.
tossups.answer: An Enquiry Concerning Human Understanding [prompt on Hume’s Enquiry]
tossups.answer_formatted: An Enquiry Concerning Human Understanding [prompt on Hume’s Enquiry]

tossups.question: A second, “suppressor” one of these devices is used to control for matrix effects in one technique. W Clark Still introduced an air pressure-driven “flash” technique that uses a short one of these devices. The graph of the efficiency of these devices as a function of u has a “Nike swoosh” shape. Flexible fused-silica wall-coated examples of these devices are tightly coiled in an oven that is gradually heated in temperature (*) programming. The A term of one equation is zero for open tubular examples of these devices. These devices are packed with polymer beads in a technique that separates analytes by molecular size. The retention time is the duration a compound spends in one of these devices before eluting. For 10 points, name these devices through which the mobile phase flows in gas and liquid chromatography.
tossups.answer: chromatography columns [prompt on chromatography devices or chromatography apparatuses by asking, “What part?;” prompt on capillaries]
tossups.answer_formatted: chromatography columns [prompt on chromatography devices or chromatography apparatuses by asking, “What part?; ” prompt on capillaries]

tossups.question: A monarch who reigned during this century was profiled in the Paschal Chronicle and a history by the Armenian bishop Sebeos. The issue of Monothelitism was addressed during this century by a monarch, whose defeat at the Battle of Ongal allowed for Asparukh’s creation of a Bulgarian state. The themata system was developed during this century by (*) Constantine II. During this century, an early use of Greek fire repelled a four-year siege of Constantinople by Mu’awiyah I. The True Cross was recovered to Constantinople during this century after Heraclius defeated a Sassanid invasion. For 10 points, name this century in which the Byzantine Empire receded with the rise of the Rashidun Caliphate after the death of Muhammad.
tossups.answer: 7th century [or 600s]

tossups.question: In a funerary sculpture, a noblewoman of these people with her name inscribed across her chest leans on a pillow and adjusts a veil. These people developed pottery with a glossy black finish known as bucchero. A goat’s head emerges from the back of a bronze sculpture of this civilization. Recent analysis indicates a boar vessel attributed to these people may actually date to the 20th century. A terracotta sculpture of a god with stylized braids and a white toga striding forwards stood on the (*) roof of a temple of this civilization at Portonaccio. These people sculpted a reclining, banqueting couple on the Sarcophagus of the Spouses. This civilization created the Chimera of Arezzo. For 10 points, a sculpture of Apollo at Veii and painted tombs at Tarquinia were created by what pre-Roman civilization?
tossups.answer: Etruscans [accept Villanovan culture] (The first clue refers to the Sarcophagus of Seianti Hanunia Tlesnasa.)
tossups.metadata: The first clue refers to the Sarcophagus of Seianti Hanunia Tlesnasa.

tossups.question: In one story by this author, a schoolmaster throws a head-shaped jar back into the sea after discovering that Stoll recovered it from a shipwreck, then drowned. While listening to the “tearing sound of splintering wood,” the protagonist of another story by this author decides to smoke his last cigarette and switches on a silent radio broadcast. In that story, the Triggs die during an event that only occurs at (*) high tide. This author of a story about Nat Hocken also wrote a novel in which the protagonist wears a dress previously worn by the title character after being tricked by the villainous Mrs. Danvers. In that novel by this author, the unnamed narrator and Maxim de Winter discover that Manderley has burned down. For 10 points, name this author of “The Birds” and Rebecca.
tossups.answer: Daphne du Maurier (The story in the first line is “Not After Midnight.”)
tossups.metadata: The story in the first line is “Not After Midnight.”

bonuses.leadin: One translation of this poet’s work describes a “lovely laughing” that “puts the heart in my chest on wings” and frequently makes use of empty brackets. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this ancient Greek poet of “Ode to Aphrodite,” whose poetic fragments were recently translated in the collection If Not, Winter. This “Tenth Muse” lived on the island of Lesbos.

This Canadian author translated the “fragments of Sappho” for her book If Not, Winter. This woman wrote about an ambiguous love triangle between Geryon, Herakles, and Ancash in her verse novel Autobiography of Red.

Autobiography of Red begins with a translation of this author’s fragmented poem Geryoneis, which serves as the basis for the novel. Lille University names a papyrus containing some poems attributed to this ancient lyric poet.

bonuses.leadin: The Central African Republic ranks first in global consumption per capita of this substance due to the Ba’aka (“BAH-kah”) people’s dependence on it. For 10 points each:
answers: Pitcairn Islands [or Pitcairn, Henderson, Ducie and Oeno Islands or Pitkern, Henderson, Ducie a’ Oeno Ailen]
Nepal [or Federal Democratic Republic of Nepal or Saṅghīya Loktāntrik Gaṇatantra Nepāl]
parts: Name this substance. The Yao people of Malawi and Mozambique harvest this substance from beehives with the help of namesake “guide” birds.
These islands are renowned for producing high-quality honey popular among British royalty. Many inhabitants of this British territory descend from Bounty mutineers and their Tahitian captives.

The documentary “The Last Honey Hunter” follows Maule Dhan Rai (“MOH-lee dun RYE”), one of the last members of the Gurung people to scale cliffs in this country to collect hallucinogenic honey. The Gurung people inhabit areas in this country south of the Annapūrṇa Conservation Area.
answers_formatted: Pitcairn Islands [or Pitcairn, Henderson, Ducie or Oeno Islands or Pitkern, Henderson, Ducie a’ Oeno Ailen]
Nepal [or Federal Democratic Republic of Nepal or Saṅghīya Loktāntrik Gaṇatantra Nepāl]
acceptable: Pitkern, Henderson, Ducie a’ Oeno Ailen

bonuses.leadin: In this piece, the soloist enters with a descending fifth from E to A, then arpeggiates an A minor chord from E to an E one octave higher, and then plays a descending fourth from F to C. For 10 points each:
answers: Introduction and Rondo Capriccioso, Op. 28 [or Introduction et Rondo Capriccioso, Op. 28]
parts: Name this piece. Pizzicato strings accompany two animato bursts in the Andante malinconico opening of this piece, whose premiere was so successful that it was published separately rather than as one violin concerto’s finale.

This musician premiered Saint-Säens’s Introduction et Rondo Capriccioso. His own flashy pieces include one that opens with an Aragonaise and paraphrases movements such as a seguidilla “by the ramparts” from another work.

That aforementioned “fantasy” paraphrases this work, whose composer transcribed Introduction and Rondo Capriccioso for violin and piano. Saint-Säens drew inspiration for the main violin motif in his Havanaise from this Bizet opera’s habanera.
answers_formatted: Introduction and Rondo Capriccioso, Op. 28 [or Introduction et Rondo Capriccioso, Op. 28]

bonuses.leadin: English colonial officials required salvagers to pay a “royal tenth” of profits to operate on these sites. For 10 points each:
answers: shipwrecks [or answers like sunken ships or sunken vessels; prompt on answers like ships or vessels]
piracy [accept word forms like pirates or pirating; accept privateers or privateering; prompt on criminal act or crime by asking, “What is the name given to those who commit this crime?”]
parts: Name these sites. In a popular scientific history book, Dava Sobel details how the discovery of one of these sites prompted the Royal Academy to encourage John Harrison’s development of chronometer prototypes to prevent similar disasters.

When unsanctioned, salvagers were known as “wreckers” and their operations were considered this type of act. The English employed Francis Drake to commit this type of act, robbing enemy vessels of stowed valuables.

Salvager Jacque Francis became the first person of African descent called as a witness in an English court when he gave a testimony on this vessel, sunk during the reign of Henry VIII. Margaret Rule led the project to raise this vessel in 1982 to its current location in a Portsmouth museum.
answers_formatted: shipwrecks [or answers like sunken ships or sunken vessels; prompt on answers like ships or vessels]
piracy [accept word forms like pirates or pirating; accept privateers or privateering; prompt on criminal act or crime by asking, “What is the name given to those who commit this crime?]
promptable: crime by asking, “What is the name given to those who commit this crime?

bonuses.leadin: A metaplasia called Barrett’s esophagus may result from leaving this condition untreated. For 10 points each:
answers: acid reflux disease [or gastroesophageal reflux disease; or GERD]

antidepressants [accept tricyclic antidepressants; prompt on any of SSRIs, selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors, SNRIs, or serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors by asking, “What broader class of drugs are those part of?”]
parts: Name this condition caused by a relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter that allows gastric fluid to flow backwards out of the stomach, causing heartburn. Proton pump inhibitors treat this condition.
Besides PPIs, antagonists of this compound’s H2 receptors are another common GERD treatment. This compound’s H1 receptors are inhibited by medications like loratadine.

While GERD results in abnormal esophageal exposure to acid, even physiological amounts of acid may cause heartburn in patients with hypersensitive esophagi, requiring treatment with this broad class of pain-modulating drugs instead of PPIs or H2 inhibitors.
answers_formatted: antidepressants [accept tricyclic antidepressants; prompt on any of SSRIs, selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors, SNRIs, or serotonin or norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors by asking, “What broader class of drugs are those part of?]
promptable: any of SSRIs, selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors, SNRIs,
norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors by asking, “What broader class of drugs are those part of?

bonuses.leadin: Sub-brown dwarfs differ from brown dwarfs in that their mass is below the limiting mass for the thermonuclear fusion of this isotope. For 10 points each:
answers: deuterium [or H-2 or Hydrogen-2 or heavy hydrogen; accept D or 2H; do not accept or prompt on “hydrogen”]
parts: Name this isotope that undergoes its namesake “burning” as it fuses with a proton in the second step of the proton-proton chain.

Since deuterium produced in stars is destroyed, nearly all deuterium found in nature is thought to have been created during a period of nucleosynthesis following this event that started the universe’s rapid expansion.

This probe measured the baryon-photon ratio, revealing how abundant light elements were after Big Bang nucleosynthesis. This probe's observations in the early 2000s helped solidify the Lambda-CDM model.
answers_formatted: deuterium [or H-2 or Hydrogen-2 or heavy hydrogen; accept D or 2H; do not accept or prompt on "hydrogen"]

bonuses.leadin: In the Wedding Trousseau Items Size Manual, woodblock prints describe various recommended items for Edo-era dowries. Answer the following about some of the art that was included, for 10 points each.
parts: Incense and shells for bridal games were often given in boxes decorated with this material, which is sprinkled with gold powder in the maki-e technique. Furnishings with carvings in this red-and-black material were also gifts.

The lacquer boxes, decorated with cranes, pines, and other symbols of longevity, might also contain inkstones used for this art form. Brushes are used to write strokes in specific orders in this art form.
Wedding trousseaus also included these objects, which Ogata Kōrin painted with Red and White Plum Blossoms on either side of a swirling brook and with Irises against backdrops of gold leaf.

bonuses.leadin: A traveler’s song named for this entity remarks that the listener hardly hears a breath when the birds are silent in the woods before noting that the listener will rest too. For 10 points each:
answers: the night [or die Nacht; accept “Wanderer’s Nightsong” or “Wandrers Nachtlied”; accept Hymns to the Night or Hymnen an die Nacht]
Novalis [or Georg Philipp Friedrich Freiherr von Hardenberg]
parts: Name this entity. The speaker of a poem titled for this entity describes it as a “silent messenger of secrets infinite” after asking, “what living, sentient thing loves not the all-joyous light?”

This German author of Hymns to the Night created the recurring motif of the blue flower as a symbol for Romanticism in his unfinished novel about the musings of a young poet, Heinrich von Ofterdingen.
The blue flower may have inspired the search for the mythical “Urpflanze” in this author’s Metamorphosis of Plants. This author of two “Wanderer’s Nightsongs” also wrote The Sorrows of Young Werther.
answers_formatted: the night [or die Nacht; accept Wanderer’s Nightsong or Wandrers Nachtlied; accept Hymns to the Night or Hymnen an die Nacht]
acceptable: Georg Philipp Friedrich Freiherr von Hardenberg

bonuses.leadin: This was the first of two decades whose economic growth was addressed by the Berg Report and the rival Lagos Plan of Action. For 10 points each:
answers: Ethiopia [or Federal Democratic Republic of Ethiopia or Ityop’iya Federalawi Demokrasiyawi Ripeblik]
parts: Name this “Lost Decade” of economic development in sub-Saharan Africa, characterized by neoliberal economic policies pushed by the IMF and the World Bank.
Upon taking office in 1985, this leader abandoned the socialist economic policy of ujamaa outlined in the Arusha Declaration, instead accepting neoliberal structural adjustment programs.

A refusal by Mengistu Haile Mariam and the Derg government to accept foreign aid coupled with neoliberal economic reforms exacerbated a 1980s famine in this East African country governed from Addis Ababa.
answers_formatted: Ethiopia [or Federal Democratic Republic of Ethiopia or Ityop’iya Federalawi Demokrasiyawi Ripeblik]

bonuses.leadin: Kanada authored this school’s sutra, which contains an early description of gravity and the principle that “every action has an equal and opposite reaction.” For 10 points each:
answers: the four elements [or the five elements; accept ether, earth, fire, air, AND water]
parts: Name this orthodox school of Hindu philosophy closely linked to the Nyaya school. This school held that the world is made up of paramāṇus, and believed the only two valid pramanas to be inference and perception.
The Vaisheshika’s paramāṇus are these objects, which are eternal and each have their own individuality. Democritus’s natural philosophy is based on these fundamental, indivisible units of matter.

With the exception of akasha, the paramāṇus make up the pancha bhutas, or these things, within the Vaisheshika school’s nine-substance classification. One cosmology identifies love and strife as the forces governing these things.
answers_formatted: the four elements [or the five elements; accept ether, earth, fire, air, AND water]
acceptable: ether, earth, fire, air, AND water

bonuses.leadin: In a 2020 Margaret Atwood short story, this character and her twin sister nicknamed “Imp” murder and then cannibalize her abusive husband. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this “patient” character whose loyalty is tested by her husband, the Marquis of Gualtieri, in the final story of the Decameron.
A clerk from Oxford relates the story of Griselda and the Marquis in one of the 24 stories from this author’s Middle English collection The Canterbury Tales.

Griselda is the final guest to arrive at a dinner party with Pope Joan, Isabella Bird, and other famous women from history in the first act of this play about Marlene’s promotion at the title employment agency.

bonuses.leadin: Rukmiṇī Devī Arundale helped revive this dance form after its performance by devadāsis in temples was banned by British officials in the name of social reform. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this classical dance from Tamiḻ Nāḍu. It consists of seven sections such as jatīsvaram and varṇam and has a characteristic araimaṇḍi (“uh-ruh-MUN-dee”) pose in which dancers bend their knees into a deep squat.
Bharatanāṭyam expresses meanings with these gestures, which include an open-palmed representation of clouds and forests. These hand gestures convey reassurance in images of the Buddha.

Bharatanāṭyam also communicates emotions through drishti bheda, specific movements of these facial features. Dancers of other forms like Kathakali also line these facial features with black kohl for emphasis.

bonuses.leadin: While based in this city, Gerard of Cremona translated Arabic texts into Latin, including Ptolemy’s Almagest. For 10 points each:
answers: Alfonso X [or Alfonso the Wise; prompt on Alfonso]
Spanish Inquisition [or Tribunal of the Holy Office of the Inquisition]
parts: Name this Iberian city home to a School of Translators during the 13th century. In 1761, Charles III inaugurated the Royal Weapons Factory in this city to produce swords from a namesake durable steel alloy.

This ruler founded universities at Salamanca and Toledo in addition to promoting translation of texts into Castilian. This ruler sponsored a set of namesake astronomical tables and granted significant freedom to the Mesta.

Francisco Jiménez de Cisneros, Archbishop of Toledo, funded the multilingual Complutensian Polyglot Bible before Ferdinand II appointed him to head this institution in 1507. This institution persecuted heretics after the issuance of the Alhambra Decree.
answers_formatted: Spanish Inquisition [or Tribunal of the Holy Office of the Inquisition]
acceptable: Tribunal of the Holy Office of the Inquisition

bonuses.leadin: These phenomena must carry energy because they would cause a bead on a stick to move back and forth and heat up from friction, according to Feynman’s “sticky-bead” argument. For 10 points each:
answers: gravitational waves [accept gravitational radiation or gravity waves]
d’Alembertian operator [accept quabla or box operator]
parts: Name these phenomena predicted by general relativity. Any mass distribution with a time-varying quadrupole moment emits these phenomena, which were detected by LIGO in 2015.

The first step in deriving gravitational waves is linearizing the field equations, which works when spacetime is a small perturbation from this manifold. This flat spacetime has the signature: minus-one, one, one, one.

After linearizing and transforming to the transverse-traceless gauge, the equation of motion of the wave in vacuum sets this operator of the perturbation equal to zero. This operator is the analog of the Laplacian in Minkowski space.

bonuses.leadin: In 1925, this man was an air mail pilot, serving the route between St. Louis and Chicago; two years later, he was world-famous and won the Orteig Prize. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this man who spent fifty-five hours solo in a Ryan monoplane in 1927 before landing in Paris. He was Time Magazine’s first-ever “Man of the Year.”

Both Lindbergh’s and Earhart’s historic flights took off from Roosevelt Field on this island. This island’s largest employer was once Grumman, which produced the F-14 Tomcat and the Lunar Excursion Module.

The first airmail route in US history was between Potomac Field in Washington, D.C. and this location on Long Island. A later event held at this location evoked the description, “moving like a tremendous machine.”

bonuses.leadin: A surah named for these creatures recounts how an army led by them was decimated. For 10 points each:
answers: the elephant [or al-fīl; accept Year of the Elephant; or Amu L’Fīl]
parts: Name these creatures which were halted when their leader, named Mahmoud, knelt down and refused to enter the gates of Mecca. “Stones of clay” that were rained down onto these animals’ handlers destroyed that army named for them.

The “stones of clay” were released by the abābīl, a potentially-mythical group of this broad class of normal animals. One of these creatures called a hudhud flew messages between Suleiman and Bilqis, the Queen of Sheba.
Qur’anic scholars have noted how Surah al-Fil serves as a warning to these people who name the surah following it about their responsibilities as the custodians of Baytullah, or the House of God.
answers_formatted: the elephant [or al-fīl; accept Year of the Elephant; or Amu L’Fīl]

bonuses.leadin: Linguist John McWhorter has argued that this group of people are “bidialectal” in defending them against the claim that they are “killing the English language.” For 10 points each:
answers: young people [accept answers like youths or teenagers or millennials or Generation Z-ers or zoomers or young adults or twenty-somethings]
cot-caught merger [or caught-cot merger or don-dawn merger or dawn-don merger]
parts: Name this group of people. These people’s increased usage of and familiarity with social media has increased the use of Internet slang in the English of members of this general age group.

An example of media influence on youth speech is this lower back vowel merger prevalent in the Western US, particularly Hollywood. Rachael Tatman mapped Twitter users resisting this merger who may respell “on” as “A-W-N.”

The usage of “whom” among young people has also declined as words that undergo this process have fallen into disuse. Conjugation of verbs and declension of nouns are types of this process of word modification.
answers_formatted: young people [accept answers like youths or teenagers or millennials or Generation Z-ers or zoomers or young adults or twenty-somethings]
cot-caught merger [or caught-cot merger or don-dawn merger or dawn-don merger]

bonuses.leadin: Anne Lescot and Laurence Magoire’s Of Men and Gods documents the lives of gay practitioners of this religion, many of whom occupy female-coded spaces like the market and beauty salon. For 10 points each:
answers: Erzulie [or Ezili or Erzili; accept Erzulie Freda or Erzulie Dantò] (The quote is from “Songs for Ezili: Vodou Epistemologies of (Trans) gender” by Omise'eke Natasha Tinsley.)
horses [or cheval or chevaux or chwal]
parts: Name this Haitian religion. Female loa can possess male practitioners during ceremonies of this religion.

Loa with this name protect queer Vodou practitioners because they "love all femininity and sexuality equally." The coquettish mulatta Freda and the fierce, dark-skinned Dantò are contrasting loa with this name.
Erzulie Freda displaces the gros bon ange (“grow bone onzh”) of her devotees of all genders, analogized to these animals, during possession.
answers_formatted: Erzulie gender” by Omise'eke Natasha Tinsley.) [or Ezili or Erzili; accept Erzulie Freda or Erzulie Dantò]
acceptable: Erzulie gender” by Omise'eke Natasha Tinsley.)
Erzulie gender” by Omise'eke Natasha Tinsley.)

bonuses.leadin: This author used “a slim, dead, almost dainty young man of about twenty” to argue that “story-truth is truer sometimes than happening-truth” in the short story “Good Form.” For 10 points each:
answers: Paris (The unnamed novel is Going After Cacciato.)
parts: Name this author. In a short story collection by this author, the title objects were “largely determined by necessity,” and included “pocket knives,” “packets of Kool-Aid,” “C Rations,” and “two or three canteens of water.”

O’Brien’s collection The Things They Carried is set during this conflict. A “man of two faces” witnesses the fall of Saigon during this conflict in Viet Thanh Nguyen’s (“VEE-uht taan NWIN’S”) novel The Sympathizer.

In Nguyen’s sequel to The Sympathizer, The Committed, the nameless narrator becomes a drug dealer in this city. Paul Berlin meets Sarkin Aung Wan while following a deserting soldier to this city in a novel by O’Brien.
metadata: The unnamed novel is Going After Cacciato.

bonuses.leadin: STO-3G and 6-31G are examples of basis sets whose atomic orbitals have this property. For 10 points each:
parts: Give this property. For computational efficiency, Slater-type orbitals are expressed as linear combinations of functions with this property, which names a John Pople-developed computational chemistry software suite.
Most basis sets in computational chemistry are sets of these orbitals, which are linearly combined to form molecular orbitals. These orbitals are classified as s, p, d, or f.

Unlike the rigid rotor’s spherical harmonics or harmonic oscillator’s eigenfunctions, basis sets of atomic orbitals typically lack this property, because individual atomic orbitals overlap. Taking the inner product of any two members of a basis with this property yields 1 if they are equal and 0 otherwise.
